params.text:
SECTION 01

Ask an Interesting Question
Supervised Learning - Geoscience

Machine learning algorithms can indeed function as a magic box that can perform the task without any theoretical rules. However, they can do much better if they are built with the domain knowledge in mind.
Introduction: Prediction of Mean Annual Rainfall from Other Meteorological Statistics

• The goal of this notebook is to help you understand the fundamental idea of developing a meteorological analysis model using supervised learning algorithms.
  •  In this small research project, we will build a model that can predict mean annual rainfall from other statistics, including maximum annual rainfall, altitude, etc.

This notebook is based on the following tutorial: *Hartmann, K., Krois, J., Rudolph, A. (2023): Statistics and Geodata Analysis using R (SOGA-R). Department of Earth Sciences, Freie Universitaet Berlin. https://www.geo.fu-berlin.de/en/v/soga-r/index.html*
Reading 1: Meteorological Inference

Meteorological inference, or predicting meteorological property from other properties at the same time, can achieve the following goals:

1. Data-Driven Insights: by analyzing correlations between meteorlogical and geological statistics, we may gain more insights into how they work together to build a very much intricate phenomenon: weather.

2. Model Validation: we are often more interested in predicting the weather in the future rather than for the weather in the past. However, by testing the model for the past, we can make a better model for the future.

3. Improved Understanding of Local Conditions: Some properties may not be measurable for all locations. We can use our model to understand the conditions in such locations.

SECTION 02

Get the Data & Explore
Supervised Learning - Geoscience

Now that we have an interesting question to investigate, we will now search for the data to learn from. In this chapter, you will learn how to import data from an external source to Orange and to explore them to design your next steps.
Reading 2: Deutsche Wetterdienste

We will collect our data from the German Weather Service (Deutscher Wetterdienste, DWD), which is a government institution of Germany responsible for weather forecast and many more. If interested, you can visit their database and explore their collection: https://www.dwd.de/DE/leistungen/cdc/cdc_ueberblick-klimadaten.html

Instructions 01:

Select “File” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

Activity 2-1: Importing the Data

In this acitivity, we will download our wine data from the Deutsche Wetterdienste

Instructions 02:

Double click on the ‘File’ widget to open its settings. Copy the following URL to the Source and Orange will import the file from the website: https://userpage.fu-berlin.de/soga/data/raw-data/DWD.csv

Instructions 03:

By clicking on the data icon with the number ‘599’ on the bottom-left corner, you can open a new window where you can explore the data in detail. Take a moment to observe how the data look like.

SECTION 03

Explore the Data
Supervised Learning - Geoscience

There are a lot of features in the data that we just downloaded to Orange. Which astrological features can we use to predict the average rainfall? We will first use a statistical measure called 'correlation' to see which features are most 'correlated' to average rainfall.
Reading 3: Correlation

Correlation is a statistical measure that tells us how two sets of data are related to each other. Imagine you have two sets of numbers, like the amount of studying you do and your test scores. Correlation helps us see if there's a connection between them.

If they have a positive correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go up too. For example, if you study more, your test scores might also go up.

If they have a negative correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go down. For instance, if you spend more time watching TV, your test scores might decrease.

And if there's no correlation, it means there's no clear relationship between the two sets of data. So correlation helps us understand how changes in one thing might relate to changes in another thing.
Questions 3: Correlation

choices.question: What does a correlation coefficient of -0.9 between two variables indicate?
answers:
There is a strong negative relationship between the variables.

There is a weak negative relationship between the variables.

There is a strong positive relationship between the variables.

There is no relationship between the variables.

choices.question: Which statistical measure assesses the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables?
What statistical method is used to determine how closely two sets of data are related to each other?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Before we calculate the correlations, we will use 'Select Columns' widget from 'Transform' tab to specify the features between which the correlation will be calculated.

Activity 3: Exploring Correlations

In this acitivity, we will calculate the correlation between average rainfall and each of the other vectors and use the one with the strongest correlation to predict the average rainfall.

Instructions 02:

We wll select all the fatures except ID, DWD_ID, Federal State, Station name, and period, as it makes little to no sense to predict the average rainfall from the name of the station and similar goes for other features.

Instructions 03:

Now that we have specified the columns, we will add the correlations widget from 'unsupervised' tab and link it to the select columns widget.

Instructions 04:

Select 'MEAN_ANNUAL_RAINFALL' as we only need to see the correlation between the mean rainfall and other features. This will show that the mean annual rainfall has the strongest correlation with the MAX_RAINFALL value.

SECTION 04

Model the Data
Supervised Learning - Geoscience

We have figured out that max rainfall is the most strongly correlated to mean rainfall. We will first use 'single regression' to use max rainfall for prediction and then explore 'multiple regression' where other values will also be used for prediction.
Reading 4: Regression

Regression analysis is a statistical method used to understand the relationship between one dependent variable and one or more independent variables.

In single regression, we're looking at the relationship between one dependent variable and one independent variable. For example, if we're trying to predict someone's weight (dependent variable) based on their height (independent variable), we'd use single regression. It helps us understand how changes in one variable (height) might affect changes in another variable (weight).
Questions 4: Regression

choices.question: Which statistical method is used to predict one variable based on the values of another variable (or variables)?
Which statistical technique is used to predict a dependent variable based on one independent variable in a simple model?
answers:
Single regression analysis

Correlation analysis

Multiple regression analysis

Variance analysis

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Now that we have seen how strong the correlation between ‘max rainfall’ and ‘mean rainfall’ is, we will use ‘max rainfall’ to predict the mean rainfall of the region. Add Select Columns widget from Transform tab and link it to the dataset.

Activity 4-1: Single Regression

In this acitivity, we will create a regression model to predict mean rainfall from max rainfall.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the select columns widget to open a new window. We will only use max rainfall, so move all other features to 'Ignored', MAX_RAINFALL to 'Features', and MEAN_ANNUAL_RAINFALL to 'Target'.

Instructions 03:

Add 'Select Rows' widget from transform tab and link it to the select columns widget. There are some measurements with missing mean or max rainfall values, so we will remove them before we feed the data to the model.

Instructions 04:

Double click on the select rows widget to open the settings. You can click on the 'Add Condition' button at the bottom to add a new condition. Give two conditions in total that select only the rows with max and mean rainfall defined. The rows that are not selected in this widget will then be ignored in the later steps.

Instructions 05:

We will then add 'Data Sampler' widget from transform tab to divide the data into test and train data.

Instructions 06:

Double click on the select rows widget to see its settings. We will keep it as the default setting for now.

Instructions 07:

Add a 'Linear Regression' widget from the model tab. Do not link it to any previous widget yet.

Instructions 08:

Then add a 'Test and Score' widget from 'Evaluate' tab and link it to the linear regression widget and the data sampler widget. The data sampler widget should pass Data Sample as Data and the linear regression widget Learner.

Instructions 09:

Double click on the test and score widget to open a new window. This will show us some evaluation metrics of our model. We will explore them in depth at a later chapter, but for now, we will use scatter plot to see how well the prediction went.

Instructions 10:

Add a Scatter Plot widget from Visualize tab. Link it to the test and score widget.

Instructions 11:

Double click on the scatter plot widget to see the scatter plot. You can see that most data points are aligned in a linear fashion, but not entirely. Could we do any better?
Reading 4-2: Multiple Regression

Multiple regression expands on this concept by considering more than one independent variable to predict a single dependent variable. For instance, if we want to predict someone's income (dependent variable), we might consider their education level, years of experience, and age (independent variables). Multiple regression allows us to understand how these multiple factors together influence the outcome.

Instructions 1:

Add a 'Select Rows' column from transform tab and link it to the correlations widget. This time, we skipped 'Select Columns' step, as all features will be used for prediction.

Activity 4-2: Multiple Regression

In this acitivity, we will perform multiple regression on our data to use all features for the prediction of mean annual rainfall.

Instructions 2:

Double click on the widget to open a new window. This time, only the rows with undefined mean annual rainfall will be ignored as measurements with one or few missing values can still contain important informations for prediction.

Instructions 03:

Next, we will add ‘Data Sampler’ widget from ‘Transform’ tab and add it to the workflow. This widget will randomly split the data into ‘test’ and ‘train’ datasets, where train data is used to train the model and test data is used to test the model.

Instructions 04:

Add a 'Linear Regression' widget from the model tab. Do not link it to any previous widget yet. Note that we can use the same widget because single regression is in fact, a special case of multiple regression.

Instructions 05:

Then add a 'Test and Score' widget from 'Evaluate' tab and link it to the linear regression widget and the data sampler widget. The data sampler widget should pass Data Sample as Data and the linear regression widget Learner.

Instructions 06:

Double click on the test and score widget to open a new window. This will show us some evaluation metrics of our model. We will explore them in depth at a later chapter, but you can indeed compare this to the results from single regression.

Instructions 07:

Before we move on to compare both regressions with evaluation metrics, we will use scatter plot to visualize our prediction. Add a scatter plot widget from visualize tab and link it to our workflow.

Instructions 08:

Double click on the scatter plot widget. Give 'linear regression' for the x axis and 'mean annual rainfall' for the y axis. You could choose another feature for the x axis and compare the results on this window. Is the result better with 'linear regression' then 'max rainfall'?

SECTION 05

Communicate the Results
Supervised Learning - Geoscience

Congratulations on building your Regression model! We could see that the predictions were indeed acceptable through scatter plots, but how good are these predictions? To communicate the performance of your model, we need to know the metrics to evalute the model.
Reading 5: Evaluation Metrics

Here are some metrics that Orange supports to evalute a model.

Accuracy: Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?

Precision: Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?

Recall: Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?

f1-score: A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

MCC: Stands for Mathew's Correlation Coefficient, also called Phi coefficient. Another combined score that is also 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

Instructions 01:

Double clicking on the test and score widget will give us such evaluation metrics. Re-visit the workflow and check the metrics to see how much better multiple regression was compared to the single regression.

Activity 5: Evaluating the Model

After making predictions, we can use them to evaluate our model. Orange gives such information directly from the "Test and Score" widget.
Questions 5: Evaluating the Model

choices.question: Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.
Which of the following is the closest to the Precision of our model?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.
